text: The results are in, and we have finished outside of the top two. It was a close, hard fought race that we should all be proud of. While this isn’t the result we had hoped for, I wanted to thank everyone who was a part of this campaign for believing in the power of us. Though we will not advance to a runoff, we accomplished something great.  This campaign was consistently underestimated. I ran as a progressive, as a Latina, and as a working mom. We ran this campaign unapologetically, and we all have so much to be proud of for what we’ve accomplished. We don’t accomplish anything without taking risks. This campaign was a risky proposition– but it’s nothing compared to the risks that I’ve asked Texan workers and families to take over the course of my career. It’s their courage that inspired me to run to represent our state.  This is just the beginning of the progressive Texas we are going to build together. Congratulations to MJ for Texas and Senator Royce West for advancing in the #txsen race. Let’s do this– onwards in the fight to #FlipTexas!

I am used to being underestimated, but you can ask any construction company or politician that ever had to go up against me if they regretted underestimating me and the people I represent. Discounting me just makes me work twice as hard to prove people wrong and stand up for what I believe in. I believe in the power of us, the power of ordinary people to change the course of history. I’ve taken on some of the most powerful special interest groups in our state and won. I won higher wages and safer working conditions for tens of thousands of Texans at the Workers Defense Project. I have led the fight to make college more affordable and protect the right of every American to #vote. It’s served those in power to underestimate us individually and collectively, to try and divide us, to try and make us believe we do not share the same interests as black, brown and white Texans; as LGBTQ and straight Texans; as immigrants and American-born. They do this to distract us from their own failures, from their own greed. They care more about holding on to power and pocketing the wealth our work creates than about our needs and our families. We are coming together to change this. Those in power might underestimate the power of ordinary Texans, but we are about to prove them wrong in 2020 because we know that in Texas, we can dream big because we are big.

I’m proud to announce that our campaign is adding to our policy platform by supporting Rep. Ayanna Pressley’s legislation on criminal legal reform, The People’s Justice Guarantee, and the fundamental six policy points behind it, known as the #JusticeGuarantee. Last December, Trump announced his “Remain in Mexico” policy, which forces asylum seekers at our southern border to await a U.S. court date from Mexico. It has had disastrous humanitarian results. Around 55,000 people have been impacted by this policy.  Asylum seekers come to our border seeking safety, and we’ve left them stranded, and often at risk of facing violence. In Matamoros alone, over 1.5K people are awaiting their court date in horrific conditions with little access to medicine, clean water, and food. I went to Matamoros not only to witness what’s happening, but also to recognize the courage and resilience of those who are fighting to have a chance to call this country home. We must fight for them, too.

Today, I’m proud to announce that I’m endorsing the Peace Plan for a Safer America by students and survivors of March for Our Lives. Gun violence is a rising epidemic. Every day that our politicians fail to act is a risk to our lives and the lives of our children. We need real gun reform, urgently.  The Peace Plan is a bold gun reform plan that includes a national licensing and registry system, a ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, and a national gun buy-back program. These are the kind of ambitious policies we need to address this crisis. If we demand anything less, we’re doing the NRA’s work for it. Politicians ask for too little when they stop at universal background checks and a ban on assault weapons. Yes, we need basic, commonsense gun reforms like those. But what we’re facing is a national crisis, and what we need is visionary leadership and bold reform.  Four of the ten deadliest mass shootings in modern American history have taken place in Texas. Dozens of Texans have been shot and killed in the places where they learn, pray, and buy groceries.  These are attacks not just on our friends, families, and communities – they are attacks on our freedom and way of life, on our right to watch our loved ones leave home without wondering whether they’ll be shot dead with a weapon of war. As a mother of a two year old son, I think constantly about the day my son is going to go to kindergarten, about how it will probably be one of the most harrowing, scariest days of my life because it will be the most dangerous place I will have ever sent my child. That’s why I’m taking my lead from the young people standing up to the NRA and its politicians. That’s why I’m endorsing a plan put forward by brave survivors of gun violence. We should expect nothing less from people who seek to hold public office. Our representatives should fight for the young people, victims of gun violence and their families, and Texans that are demanding change, and not the NRA. The tragedies in El Paso and Odessa and Midland are horrific beyond words. They are also sadly, utterly predictable. Our politicians have spent my entire adult life failing to act with the urgency and moral purpose necessary to end the epidemic of gun violence.  I remember as a 17-year-old after Columbine, thinking “What is wrong with our society that things like this happen?” Now I realize that the problem is with our politicians who care more about donations from the NRA and the gun lobby than American lives.  It shouldn’t – it can’t – surprise us anymore when mass shootings like El Paso, like Odessa and Midland, like Las Vegas, Orlando, Parkland, and Columbine happen.  This isn’t even the new normal; it’s the old normal. This is the predictable result of a political system that values the profits of the gun industry more than it values human life. But it doesn’t have to be like this. Millions of Americans agree that we need gun safety laws that keep our communities safe. But to force Congress and the President to take action, we need huge numbers of people to speak up now. Will you join me in demanding real action to end gun violence? When Trump was elected, I was six-months pregnant with my son Santi. I cried in bed for several days after the election. Like millions of people across the country and around the world, I felt afraid and I felt angry – and, initially, I felt paralyzed. But then I got busy. I decided to organize a Love Trumps Hate event for my friends, family and neighbors to speak out against Trump’s hateful rhetoric.  It felt good to be in motion, to be working instead of just sitting around feeling afraid and angry. I figured that, if we were lucky, maybe a couple hundreds people would be there. Instead, over 2,000 people showed up to stand up for immigrant and Latino families like mine. That event was the start of Jolt, the organization I started and led since 2016. Since then, we’ve worked to protect the rights of immigrants and their families from attacks by the state legislature, advocated for college affordability, and registered and mobilized thousands of young voters of color. With a new baby on the way, it wasn’t really the right time in my life to start a statewide civil rights organization. But, when I thought about the ways the Trump raised the stakes for families like mine, it didn’t feel like there was any other choice but to get to work. I’m running for Senate because, when I imagine the world Santi is going to inherit, and the one I leave behind for him, I want him to be proud of what I stood up for. What we stood up for together. I want him to know that in a moment where 1 in 6 Texans didn’t have access to healthcare and millions were struggling just to make ends meet, when communities were being pitted against one another on the basis of race, and our world was at the brink of an imminent climate catastrophe, we came together and worked as hard as we could to make his life and other children’s lives like him better.

I’ll never forget this day in 2013. I got to share a moment with these two incredibly powerful women – two women who have been role models for me throughout my life and who have taught me how to stand up for what I believe in: My mom, Ana, and labor leader Dolores Huerta. My mom taught me to be everything that I love about Texans: Big, bold, kind, generous, proud, hard-working, and, above all, to care for our family, friends, and community.  As an adult, I’ve carried those values with me everywhere. While I was getting my undergraduate degree in Austin, I started organizing with construction workers and co-founded the Workers Defense Project to help ensure that hard-working families could have good, safe jobs.  At the time this photo was taken, I was the Executive Director of the Workers Defense Project. Dolores had agreed to be the keynote speaker at an event we organized, and she spoke to us about the power of ordinary people to change the country. I want to share a little bit about who I am, where I came from, and what it taught me. This is a photo of me at age two (I’m the one in the middle holding the doll) with my mom and dad, my brother and sister, my great grandmother, my uncles, my aunt, and my cousin. My mom is to my right holding my sister, and that’s my dad right behind her. We were living in the Oak Cliff neighborhood of Dallas on Glenhaven Boulevard at the time. My mom’s the oldest of nine kids from a farm-working family in Southern Mexico, and my dad’s an entrepreneur from Ohio. Growing up in a mixed-race family in Oak Cliff and, later, Columbus, Ohio, I was a part of two very different worlds.  On my dad’s side of the family, we were white and middle class. On my mom’s side of the family, we were brown and working class. I remember how differently my siblings and I were treated when we would walk into a meeting with a teacher or a doctor appointment holding my mother’s hand, who was dark skinned and spoke English with an accent, than we were treated when with my white American father. That experience taught me an early and important lesson – that, in America, it’s often the case that the color of your skin or your family’s country of origin or how much money you make shapes in profound ways how other people treat you. But, for every lesson I learned about the things that divide us, I learned more about what we have in common and what brings us together. I learned that, even if we look different, speak different languages, or come from different communities, we all want the same things – for our families to be safe, healthy, and treated with respect. These are the experiences I’m carrying with me as I run for Senate. In Texas, racial and economic inequality are very real. But so are our aspirations and our shared hope for a Texas where everyone can live with dignity.

Texas is at the epicenter of the most pressing issues facing our nation: immigration, climate change, income inequality, health care, and mass incarceration. I’m running for Senate because I believe that if we change the politics of Texas and tackle these issues head on, we change the politics of the entire country.

I think a lot about the lessons I’ve learned of courage and generosity from the people I’ve worked with throughout my life, and one of the first people that comes to mind is someone very special to me. His name is José -- here’s a picture of us and his two beautiful daughters. I met José after moving to Austin. I had learned that some of the hardest working people in the city, construction workers, were frequently not getting paid for their work and were getting seriously injured on the job.  So I started organizing alongside workers like José to demand fair wages and working conditions. I found it outrageous that many were living below the poverty line even though they worked full time. That they were statistically more likely to die on the job than any other state.  While Texas politicians were out there bragging about the miraculous growth of the economy, for workers - who are the backbone of Texas’ economy - that economic “miracle” was a nightmare. So my colleague, Emily Timm, and I co-founded the Workers Defense Project to fight for economic justice. The people I met during my time at the Workers Defense Project taught me a lot about the kind of leader I want to be. They give me the courage to run for U.S. Senate so that we can have a government that understands our community; one that can represent everyday Texans like us.

Greg Abbott sent out this fundraising letter one day before one of the deadliest hate crimes in U.S. history unfolded. What happened in El Paso, TX is a tragic consequence of the politics of hate and our representatives scapegoating immigrants for their own failure to tackle the issues that affect our state. This is the kind of hatred, the kind of vitriol that allows people to feel like they can target us on the streets in our communities.

When Trump was elected, I was six-months pregnant with my son Santi. I cried in bed for several days after the election. Like millions of people across the country and around the world, I felt afraid and I felt angry – and, initially, I felt paralyzed. But then I got busy. I decided to organize a Love Trumps Hate event for my friends, family and neighbors to speak out against Trump’s hateful rhetoric.  It felt good to be in motion, to be working instead of just sitting around feeling afraid and angry. I figured that, if we were lucky, maybe a couple hundreds people would be there. Instead, over 2,000 people showed up to stand up for immigrant and Latino families like mine. That event was the start of Jolt, the organization I started and led since 2016. Since then, we’ve worked to protect the rights of immigrants and their families from attacks by the state legislature, advocated for college affordability, and registered and mobilized thousands of young voters of color. With a new baby on the way, it wasn’t really the right time in my life to start a statewide civil rights organization. But, when I thought about the ways the Trump raised the stakes for families like mine, it didn’t feel like there was any other choice but to get to work. I’m running for Senate because, when I imagine the world Santi is going to inherit, and the one I leave behind for him, I want him to be proud of what I stood up for. What we stood up for together. I want him to know that in a moment where 1 in 6 Texans didn’t have access to healthcare and millions were struggling just to make ends meet, when communities were being pitted against one another on the basis of race, and our world was at the brink of an imminent climate catastrophe, we came together and worked as hard as we could to make his life and other children’s lives like him better.

The Latino is Powerful welcomes everyone to explore, discover, and embrace what it means to be Latinx and civically engaged in Texas.  “The Latino is Powerful tour celebrates our culture and grounds our work in a message that empowers young people to bring about true transformative change,” says Cristina Tzintzun Ramirez, Founder and Executive Director at Jolt Action. With the 2020 presidential election and U.S. Census around the corner, what happens in Texas during the next election will have a significant impact for generations to come. And now, with two Texas presidential candidates in the running for the White House, the Lone Star State is uniquely positioned to determine the fate of our nation. “We are focused on the issues that matter to our community and highlighting the power our youth has to change the future of our state,” states Antonio Arellano, Jolt’s Communications Director. Nearly 11 million Latinos reside in Texas, and half of all people under the age of 18 are Latino. Latinos will be the majority by 2030.  “Young Latinos are the key to building a democracy and government equipped to meet the ongoing challenges and changes Texas faces.
